profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 00:33

did.abstract: Correspondence, articles, and other materials by the American music critic Max Smith (1874-1935)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The Papers are open to researchers by appointment. There are no restricted materials in the collection. Please contact the Special Collections staff to schedule an appointment.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Max Smith Papers were established in the Music Library of Yale University by Smith's brother-in-law, James P. Atkinson, in 1950.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Max Smith Papers are the physical property of the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University. Copyrights belong to the composers and authors, or their legal heirs and assigns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: MSS 8, The Max Smith Papers in the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In 3 series as follows: I. Correspondence. II. Articles. III. Miscellaneous.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Max Smith Papers contain letters to and from Smith and family members, composers, performers, and critics. Arturo Toscanini is especially well represented; in particular, there are many telegrams and letters relating to Toscanini's decision to conduct the New York Philharmonic in 1926-1927, and also to the Philharmonic's European tour in 1930 . The Papers also hold rough drafts and printed copies of articles by Smith. Smith's life and work are further documented by: programs; photographs; and miscellaneous materials.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Thomas Max Smith was born in New York on December 26, 1874. He received the A.B. from Yale in 1898, the same year as Charles Ives. He earned a law degree from Columbia and passed the New York bar, but never practiced. In 1909 he married Mary Hardy. They had no children. Smith studied music for many years, beginning at the age of eight; his teachers included Horatio Parker and Samuel Sanford at Yale. He served as a music editor and critic at the New York Press (1903-1916) and the New York American (1916-1919 and again in 1923). Thereafter he worked intermittently as a foreign music correspondent for the New York Herald Tribune. He died of a cerebral embolism on June 7, 1935.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Correspondence is organized in the following categories:

A. Letters to Max Smith, arranged in alphabetical order by the last name of the sender. Within each name, the letters are then placed in chronological order. Unidentified material is grouped together at the end of this section.
B. Letters to Arthur Toscanini, arranged as above.

C. Letters from Smith and Toscanini, arranged alphabetically by recipient. Also included in this section are letters to and from people other than Smith and Toscanini, arranged alphabetically by sender, and miscellaneous letters. Of special note is the collection of 14 copies of letters from Josef Giehrl to his parents which he wrote while studying under Liszt in Rome, 1879-1880.

D. Telegrams mostly, and letters involved with getting Toscanini to conduct the New York Philharmonic during the 1926-1927 season. These are between (among) Toscanini, Smith, and Clarence McKay (business director for the orchestra), and are arranged chronologically from May 4, 1923 to Nov. 18, 1926. A second set of telegrams relates to the European tour of the New York Philharmonic under Toscanini, which occurred in 1930.
E. Communiques to Messrs. Merrill and Hearst from Smith, and their answers concerning his resignation from post as Music Critic for the American paper, arranged chronologically.

odd.head: General
odd.p: The articles in this section are mostly typed rough drafts of newspaper articles, organized as follows:
A. Articles by Max Smith on Toscanini, reviews and criticisms of operas and singers, and critical reviews of miscellaneous concerts, arranged by topic
B. A handwritten copy of an article by Lyman ---? on Alessander Dolci, no date

did.unittitle: Articles and reviews of operas and opera singers
did.physdesc: ca. 20 items ; typed copies (mostly rough drafts)

did.unittitle: Articles and critical reviews of miscellaneous concerts
did.physdesc: ca. 10 items ; typed copies (mostly rough drafts)

did.unittitle: Article by Lyman ---? on Alessander Dolci

odd.head: General
odd.p: This section covers many varied items, including a photo, menu, contract, list of subscription rates for concerts in New York, etc. Items included here are not organized in any special fashion, but are listed individually in the register for quick identification.
